III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10171 Resident confinement room; approved
Section usage.
Description (1) A facility approved to use a resident confinement room may
place a resident in this room for the following reasons:
(e) For behavior management/confinement when a resident is in
danger of harming self or others.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth is being secluded to their room for all but one hour each
day and this is expected to continue for the duration of youth's
placement.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via phone on 11/30/23. She
reported having nothing more to add to the allegations and having
never observed Youth A in person. She also reported hearing
about Youth A being in Youth A’s bedroom for 23 of 24 hours per
day from Probation Officer during a phone meeting. Probation
Officer said during the meeting that Youth A is in the bedroom 23
of 24 hours a day because of Youth A’s behaviors.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via phone on 11/30/23.
She reported Youth A is on her caseload and currently lodged in
the facility. She also reported the facility is not equipped to provide
the services Youth A needs. There is no possible placement in the
State of Michigan and the hope is Youth A will be placed in a
facility in Arkansas in a few weeks. Foster Care Worker believes
Youth A is placed in the bedroom because this is the safest place
for Youth A at times in the facility. Youth A presents with homicidal
and suicidal ideation and if not getting the attention Youth A is
seeking, Youth A was acting out in a violent manner. Youth A is
lodged on a charge of great bodily harm less than murder and has
a concrete plan to murder her family members. Youth A has also
had several charges for assault. Foster Care Worker views Youth
A as very dangerous and the situation in the facility is providing
the best possible care at this time. Youth A was released from
Hawthorne mental facility 6 months ago after being there for two
years. Hawthorne deemed Youth A as safe thus Youth A was
released. Foster Care Worker receives daily updates on Youth A
and because Youth A’s needs are so high, believes Youth A is not
being neglected. She also reported the facility Psychologist
spends 90% of the time with Youth A and when out of the
bedroom, three staff are present because of the past violent
behavior.
Administrator 1 and Administrator 2 were interviewed face to
face at the facility on 12/1/23. Both reported Youth A is not
locked in the bedroom 24 hours a day. Youth A is going to the
school at the facility and allowed to engage in exercise activities.
The only time Youth A is in the bedroom is when Youth A
becomes dysregulated and begins to become assaultive towards
staff and other youth. The facility’s focus is to have Youth A out of
the bedroom as much as possible because, both reported it is
worst for Youth A to be in the bedroom because the isolation
2

increases stress for Youth A. Both also reported Youth A is not in
the bedroom for punishment but rather for the safety of Youth A
and others. Youth A is on Youth A’s own program because of the
mental health issues Youth A presents and Youth A will do well for
weeks at a time. Both believe Probation Officer may have
misspoken during the meeting Complainant was involved in.
Probation Officer was interviewed face to face at the facility
on 12/1/23. When asked about the report of her saying Youth A is
locked in the bedroom 23 of 24 hours, she reported reading off an
incident report of what the court ordered at one point but did not
say Youth A is locked in the bedroom 23 of 24 hours.
Psychologist was interviewed face to face at the facility on
12/1/23. She reported Youth A was involved in group with other
youth until issues began to occur. Youth A stopped cooperating
and engaged in assaultive behaviors towards other youth and
staff. Youth A would take off Youth A’s clothes in the milieu and in
front of others. Since being moved to another “pod” Youth A has
avoided kicking and biting others and not engaging in self-harming
behaviors. Staff are providing hourly reinforcements to help Youth
A get out of the bedroom and the goal is to reduce restraints.
Psychologist also reported that beginning 11/20/23, Youth A’s
behaviors began to go downhill and this is documented in the
incident notes.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 12/1/23.
Youth A was out of the bedroom and reported feeling safe and
ready to be replaced to a treatment program. Youth A believed
staff are caring and attentive to Youth A’s needs. Youth A also
reported being in the bedroom when acting out and views the
bedroom time as not punishment.
Documents Reviewed:
Youth A Modified Behavior Program 11/1/23. This document
outlines the reasons for Youth A being placed on a modified
behavior program as repeated negative behavior/interactions,
multiple physical/verbal assaults, and multiple self-harm incidents.
Youth A can earn points to be removed from this modified
behavior plan and points are to be tracked. Youth A will attend
school as Youth A’s behavior permits however, Youth A will not
attend the class with equipment/tools present and not attend final
school block because of multiple threats/interaction issues. If
Youth A’s behavior is appropriate Youth A can engage in
programing activities such as Music therapy, Bible study, Tai chi,
3

etc. Youth A is to shower each day as Youth A’s behavior permits.
Youth A’s behavior will be reviewed each day.
Kalamazoo County Juvenile Home notes on Youth A from
Psychologist dated 9/1/23 to 11/30/23. These notes cover the
contact Psychologist had with Youth A and the alert-levels Youth
A was placed on. There is also documentation of the decision for
the alert-levels and documentation of Youth A progress and/or
lack of progress during this time period. Throughout this time
frame, Youth A remained mostly on Alert level blue indicating
Youth A was considered to be at risk for self-harming or harmful
behaviors towards others. This restricted what Youth A could have
in the bedroom and the level of supervision required. It is
documented that at times Youth A would respond in a positive
manner and present as cooperative with staff and others.
However, other times, Youth A would become violent and
aggressive towards staff and other youth or engage in self-
harming behaviors. It is documented that often Youth A would
engage in threatening self-harming behaviors or threatening harm
to others. When not receiving a requested task, item, or level of
attention Youth A believed should have been provided, Youth A
often became dysregulated and engaged violence. The holding
area in the facility was used when Youth A became significantly
violent or engaged in self-harming behaviors or threats. Often
Youth A was moved from a pod to the holding area and after a
short time of cooperation, Youth A was removed back to the pod.
It is documented Youth A was under constant supervision and
Psychological was present daily and sometimes for a significant
length of time. Youth A attended school and other activities as
long as Youth A was cooperative and not engaged in violent
aggressive threats or behaviors.
9th Circuit court for county of Kalamazoo Family Division
dated 11/27/23. This court report outlines the reasons for Youth A
being lodged in the Juvenile Home and Youth A’s progress. Youth
A is being provided one-on-one supervision by staff because
Youth A has displayed behaviors stemming from past traumas
and attention seeking behaviors. Youth A has made many
statements of self-harming and has attempted to engage in self-
harming behaviors on several occasions. Youth A is placed in a
very strict program to ensure Youth A is safe. The plan is that
Youth A will be transitioned to appropriate placement as soon as
appropriate placement is found.
Special Observation list of the Pods, there is no date on this
document. This document outlines the different observation used
4

for youth in the program. Starting with the Standard Observation –
Green Alert, the next level is Blue Alert, then Yellow Alert followed
by Red Alert. With each level of alert determined by the behaviors
presented by the youth and involves a different level of
supervision. The behaviors that determine the level of alert involve
self-harming behaviors (suicidal ideation or violent acting out
towards others).
Incident Reports for Youth A from 8/31/23 to 11/28/23. During
this time frame, it is documented Youth A had 58 incident reports
over 16 days. These incidents were the result of Youth A
engaging in self-harming behaviors, threatening other youth and
staff, refusing directions, and attacking staff or other youth. Youth
A was restrained during many of these incidents and placed in
Youth A’s bedroom.
Room Observation Sheets Kalamazoo County Juvenile Home
from 11/6/23 to 11/30/23. During this time period, Youth A was
lodged in the bedroom as documented by the room check sheets.
However, documentation indicates that with the exception of one
day, Youth A was allowed out of the room to engage in different
activities such as school, therapy, showering, group involvement,
and other activities. The facility is documented as making the
required room checks on Youth A. The program, Youth A was
engaged in involved being placed in the bedroom as a
consequence of negative behaviors such as threatening or
attacking staff or other youth and engaging in self-harming
behaviors (threatened or acted upon). Documentation also
indicates the focus is to remove Youth A from the bedroom when
Youth A is cooperative and no longer dysregulated. The focus is
to protect Youth A and others when Youth A becomes
dysregulated.
Analysis Based upon interviews and written documentation there is no
evidence that supports Youth A is locked in the bedroom 23 of 24
hours per day. The facility has Youth A on a program that involves
room confinement for inappropriate aggressive behaviors with a
focus on getting Youth A out of the bedroom as soon as possible.
When lodged in the bedroom, Youth A is supervised, has access
to Psychologist, and the ability to engage in several different
activities as Youth A begins to become cooperative.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
